Restrictions vary by province, but certain places, like "red areas" in Quebec continue ban public events  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109204328/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progressive-regional-alert-and-intervention-system/level-4-maximum-alert-red/

Restrictions vary by province, but certain places, like "orange areas" in Quebec continue to cap gatherings at 6.  Winnipeg has recently lowered their gathering size to 5 to counteract the spike.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200035/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progressive-regional-alert-and-intervention-system/level-3-alert-orange/
Public transit remains open.
The federal government continues to advise people to stay at home.

Travel and quarantine restrictions are varied by province, the most extreme of which continues to be the outright ban for those outside the maritimes to enter Newfoundland.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201109204109/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/travel-restrictions/
As noted before, policy was extended. No change.
As noted before, policy was extended. No change in debt relief

While many places like Toronto, Quebec, and Manitoba are requiring masks at all indoor spaces, however certain places in New Brunswick, like Moncton, have gone further, requiring it in all public spaces. Outdoor single family yards are exempt  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109205125/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/moncton-campbellton-masks-mandatory-outside-1.5759496  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions
On 4 November, City of Toronto Public Health reinstates comprehensive contact tracing. See CAN_ON note for 4 November.

On 6 November, Alberta Health focusses contact tracing on positive test cases who might have links to 3 priority settings -- schools, health care facilities, long-term care homes -- until contact tracing backlog cleared. See CAN_AB note for 6 November.

On November 10th, the Minister of Public Services and Procurement and Minister of Health announced that the Government has signed an agreement with BD to purchase 7.6 million rapid, point-of-care, antigen tests and up to 2,172 analysers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201120222633/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-services-procurement/news/2020/11/government-of-canada-signs-another-agreement-for-covid-19-antigen-rapid-tests.html

All schools in Nunavut must close from the 18th of November and education will be conducted online.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201121180913/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/news/nunavut-moves-territory-wide-covid-19-restrictions

Beginning November 18th for a 2 week period in Nunavut, all non-essential services, business and organisations will be required to close and wherever possible, switch to work from home.  All recreation facilities will be closed, all restaurants become take-out only, and bars will be closed. All personal services such as hairstylists and masseuses must close.   All health centres and the Qikiqtani General Hospital are closed except for emergency services.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201121180913/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/news/nunavut-moves-territory-wide-covid-19-restrictions

For a 2 week period in Nunavut from the 18th November, outdoor gatherings over 5 people are no longer permitted. Indoor gatherings are restricted to 5 people in addition to household members.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201121180913/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/news/nunavut-moves-territory-wide-covid-19-restrictions

On the 19th of November, Bill C-9 received royal assent. This includes the extension of the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy until June 2021. This remains at the current rate of up to 65% of eligible wages.

On 19th of November, Bill C-9 received royal assent. This includes the new Canada Emergency Rent Subsidy. This will support businesses, charities and non-profits that have suffered revenue drop by providing support up to 65% of eligible expenses until December 19th 2020.   A new Lockdown support also provides an additional 25% through the Canada Emergency Rent subsidy for qualifying organisations that are subject to lockdown and must shut their doors under a public health order. Combined, these two measures mean businesses subject to lockdown could receive rent support of up to 90%.   https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/11/new-targeted-support-to-help-businesses-through-pandemic-receives-royal-assent.html

On 19 November, City of Toronto Public Health returns to focusing contact tracing on high-risk cases to cope with high volumes -- further confirmation of contact tracing implementation problems in different regions of Canada. See CAN_ON note for 19 November.

Still current. The Canada Emergency Response Benefit has been renamed the Canada Recovery Benefit and pays $500 per week for up to 26 weeks for workers who have stopped working or had their income reduced by at least 50% due to COVID-19, and who are not eligible for Employment Insurance (EI). EI eligibility rules have been temporarily relaxed to accommodate more COVID-related job and/or income losses.  See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126183605/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

No changes in federal programs since previous entries. Provincial governments may also have programs. Federal programs summarized on Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126183605/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

Although not as comprehensive as Nunavut’s lockdown, effective 23 November, the Province of Ontario ordered the following measures in the City of Toronto and the neighbouring Peel Region: sports and recreational facilities, personal care services and gambling establishments to close; restaurants and alcoholic drink establishments restricted to takeout; retail stores restricted to curbside pick-up or delivery except for essential providers such as grocery stores and pharmacies. See Province of Ontario website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201124144246if_/https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/59305/ontario-taking-further-action-to-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19

Effective 23 November, the Province of Ontario limited indoor public events to members of the same household and outdoor public events to a maximum of 10 people in the City of Toronto and the neighbouring Peel Region. See Province of Ontario website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201124144246if_/https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/59305/ontario-taking-further-action-to-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19

Effective 23 November, the Province of Ontario limited indoor social gatherings to members of the same household and outdoor social gatherings to a maximum of 10 people in the City of Toronto and the neighbouring Peel Region. See Province of Ontario website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201124144246if_/https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/59305/ontario-taking-further-action-to-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19

On 23 November, the chief public health officer of the Province of Manitoba “urges Manitobans to only leave their homes for essential purposes”. See Province of Manitoba website COVID-19 BULLETIN #264, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126145459/https://news.gov.mb.ca/news/index.html?item=49897&posted=2020-11-23

On 23 November, the chief public health officer of the Province of Manitoba reminded residents to “wear a mask in indoor public places”. See Province of Manitoba website COVID-19 BULLETIN #264, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126145459/https://news.gov.mb.ca/news/index.html?item=49897&posted=2020-11-23

Effective 24 November, acting on the advice of the chief public health officer of the Province of Manitoba, the Hanover School Division moved students (except children of critical services workers who cannot make alternative care arrangements) to teacher-led remote learning at home. The Red River College campus in Steinbach, Manitoba (central city of Hanover School Division) remains open for classes that require in-person instruction. See Province of Manitoba website COVID-19 BULLETIN #260, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125202852/https://news.gov.mb.ca/news/index.html?item=49882&posted=2020-11-20  See Red River College website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125212618/https://www.rrc.ca/coronavirus/on-campus-safety/levels/

Effective 24 November, the Province of Alberta banned all public events and festivals. See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125215936/https://www.alberta.ca/enhanced-public-health-measures.aspx

Effective 24 November, the Province of Alberta banned indoor social gatherings in any setting and restricted outdoor gatherings to a maximum of 10 people. See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125215936/https://www.alberta.ca/enhanced-public-health-measures.aspx

At Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s 24 November press conference, he repeated the government’s advice that “as much as possible people should stay at home”.  See press conference transcript, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126144248/https://www.rev.com/blog/transcripts/justin-trudeau-november-24-covid-19-press-conference-transcript    Effective 24 November, the Province of Alberta advised that “working from home should be considered, where possible”. See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125215936/https://www.alberta.ca/enhanced-public-health-measures.aspx

Effective 24 November, the Province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) suspended PEI’s participation in the Atlantic Bubble agreement that previously allowed residents of PEI and the three other Atlantic provinces to travel freely within the Atlantic region. Residents of other Atlantic provinces now have to apply for approval in advance of travelling to PEI, just like residents of non- Canadian provinces outside the Atlantic region. Islanders should only travel outside of PEI for essential purposes or work. Island residents do not require pre-travel approval to return to the province, but will be required to self-isolate or apply to work-isolate for 14 days upon their return if they have been outside PEI for more than one day. See Province of PEI website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126023333if_/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/news/pei-suspends-participation-atlantic-bubble-two-weeks

At Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s 24 November press conference, he stressed the importance of testing asymptomatic individuals after contact tracing identifies possible exposure and emphasized that the federal government had delivered 300,000 rapid testing kits to the Province of Alberta. See press conference transcript, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126144248/https://www.rev.com/blog/transcripts/justin-trudeau-november-24-covid-19-press-conference-transcript

Effective 24 November, the Province of British Columbia (BC) introduced fines for those who ignore the provincial health officer’s order that those aged 12 and over must wear a mask in indoor public places. See BC Government news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126181139/https://news.gov.bc.ca/releases/2020EMBC0061-001960  Effective 24 November, the Province of Alberta made masks mandatory in all indoor workplaces in the two largest cities of Calgary and Edmonton. See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125215936/https://www.alberta.ca/enhanced-public-health-measures.aspx

Effective 25 November, the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador required people arriving from the three other Atlantic provinces to self-isolate for 14 days and recommended against non-essential travel outside of Newfoundland and Labrador. Prior to 25 November, there were no restrictions on travel between Newfoundland and Labrador and the other Atlantic provinces. See Province of Newfoundland and Labrador website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126021912/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2020/exec/1123n04/

Although not as comprehensive as Nunavut’s lockdown, effective 27 November, the Province of Alberta imposed restricted access to some businesses in the two largest cities of Calgary and Edmonton as well as other districts designated as “purple zones” with a high incidence of covid-19 cases. See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125215936/https://www.alberta.ca/enhanced-public-health-measures.aspx  Although not as stringent as Nunavut’s lockdown, effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan enforced restricted access to restaurant seating and large retail stores. See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27

Although not as restrictive as some other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan restricted capacity to 30 people at all cultural, athletic, religious and gambling venues. Food or beverage service must be cordoned off from the activity area. See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27  Although not as restrictive as some other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of New Brunswick limited regularly scheduled in-person religious services, cinema and live performances to 50 participants with two metres of physical distancing and weddings and funerals to 25 in the Fredericton capital zone. See Province of New Brunswick website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127150930/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2020.11.0640.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127152622/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html

Although not as restrictive as other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan limited indoor banquets, conferences, wedding and funeral receptions in public venues to 30 people.  Food or beverages may not be present or served. The maximum size for private gatherings in the home setting remains at five (except for families larger than five who cannot host anyone outside the immediate family). See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27  Although not as restrictive as some other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of New Brunswick restricted outdoor gatherings in the Fredericton capital zone to 25 people or fewer with physical distancing also required. See Province of New Brunswick website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127150930/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2020.11.0640.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127152622/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html

Effective 27 November, people travelling into New Brunswick, including from the other Atlantic provinces, are required to self-isolate for 14 days unless exempt. Registration for travel into New Brunswick is also now mandatory, including New Brunswickers returning home. Failure to register can result in penalties. See Province of New Brunswick website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127150930/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2020.11.0640.html

Effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan extended mandatory mask wearing to all prisons, indoor fitness centres (except aquatic activities), students ages 3-12, and workers and visitors in all workplace and commercial common areas. See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27

Effective 30 November, the Province of Alberta moved all grade 7-12 students to at-home learning. In-person classes will resume 11 January after an extended winter break.  See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125213917/https://www.alberta.ca/k-to-12-school-re-entry-2020-21-school-year.aspx

On 30 November, the federal Minister of Finance announced “increasing the maximum rate of the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy to 75 per cent for the period beginning December 20, 2020 and extending this rate until March 13, 2021” https://web.archive.org/web/20201130213318/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/11/government-of-canada-releases-supporting-canadians-and-fighting-covid-19-fall-economic-statement-2020.html

On 30 November, the federal Minister of Finance announced “extending the current rates of the Canada Emergency Rent Subsidy and Lockdown Support until March 13, 2021” for businesses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130213318/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/11/government-of-canada-releases-supporting-canadians-and-fighting-covid-19-fall-economic-statement-2020.html

Effective 1 December, the Yukon Territory made it mandatory for all persons over the age of two (with very limited exceptions) to wear a mask in all indoor public spaces.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201125070821/https://yukon.ca/en/news/november-24-2020-covid-19-update

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut reopened elementary schools in some communities and reopened middle and secondary schools on some days with online learning on other days. In some communities, schools will on staggered schedules for elementary and secondary grades. The Arctic College in the capital city Iqaluit reopened for reduced numbers of students. Schools in Arviat remain closed. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut allowed some businesses and workplaces in some communities to reopen with physical distancing. Arviat remains under lockdown rules. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut allowed arenas in some regions to reopen with a limit of 50 spectators. Arenas in some communities remain closed. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut relaxed the limit on indoor gatherings to the household plus 10 or 15 people (depending on the region). Outdoor gatherings can be up to 50 people.  Arviat remains under lockdown rules. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut allowed travel to Rankin Inlet and Whale Cove, although non-essential travel is not recommended. Travel in and out of Arviat remains restricted. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia extended the order through at least 16 December in Hants County and the capital Halifax region restricting restaurants and bars to take-out and delivery service, limiting retail stores to 25% of capacity and closing fitness centres, casinos and museums. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004   https://web.archive.org/web/20201204205944/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/county-restrictions/halifax/  Interesting article in the 4 December issue of the Globe and Mail newspaper pointing out that the provinces of Ontario and Quebec are now relying on inspections of construction, warehouse and manufacturing sites in contrast to closure orders or other more restrictive measures from March to the summer re-opening. See Globe and Mail website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204170232/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-quebec-see-covid-19-outbreaks-at-workplaces-climb/

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia extended the order through at least 16 December in Hants County and the capital Halifax region banning public events and festivals (sports, arts and culture). See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004   https://web.archive.org/web/20201204205944/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/county-restrictions/halifax/

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia extended through at least 16 December in Hants County and the capital Halifax region the order limiting indoor and outdoor gatherings to the larger of 5 persons or the number of persons in a household. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004   https://web.archive.org/web/20201204205944/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/county-restrictions/halifax/

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia announced easier access to testing to asymptomatic persons and recommended testing for those aged 16 to 35 and all those who have attended social gatherings without proper distancing in the past 14 days. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004

On 4 December, Nova Scotia’s Chief Medical Officer of Health repeated his recommendation that all residents “wear a mask in indoor public places”. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004

Although not as restrictive as in some Canadian jurisdictions, effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) closed all recreational and fitness facilities, casinos, bingo halls and other gaming establishments as well as museums and libraries; restricted restaurants and bars to take-out and delivery; and imposed a 50% capacity limit on retail stores. See government of PEI website, archived  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020

Effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) banned organized sport and restricted religious, funeral and wedding services to 10 persons plus presiding officials. See government of PEI website, archived:      https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020    Public events are able to go ahead under sanitation and distancing restrictions in other provinces, hence the 2T not 2G code

Effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) restricted indoor and outdoor gatherings to 10 persons. See government of PEI website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020

Although not as prescriptive as some Canadian jurisdictions, effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) asked residents to work and shop from home whenever possible. See government of PEI website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020

Effective 8 December, the Province of Alberta prohibited all indoor and outdoor social gatherings and limited close contacts to within each household except for persons living alone restricted to 2 in-person visitors who must always be the same 2. See Government of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201211114009/https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=75859ADEA5D5E-045D-2386-0CB140C175A800DD

Effective 8 December, the Province of Alberta extended the mask requirement in indoor public spaces to the entire province. See Government of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201211114009/https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=75859ADEA5D5E-045D-2386-0CB140C175A800DD

On 9 December, Health Canada approved Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine “for use in people 16 years of age or older”. “Canada will receive up to 249,000 doses” later this month. The federal government is arranging distribution to provincial governments with the first group of high-priority recipients expected to receive vaccinations before year end. See Government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210205358/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2020/12/health-canada-authorizes-first-covid-19-vaccine0.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210210347/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-services-procurement/news/2020/12/canada-to-receive-early-delivery-of-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine.html

On 10 December, Prime Minister Trudeau repeated the Government of Canada’s commitment that the covid-19 “vaccine would be completely free for all Canadians”. See Global News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216164929/https://globalnews.ca/news/7514966/coronavirus-canada-vaccine-rollout-trudeau/

Effective Dec. 13, working from home is mandatory in the Province of Alberta when physical presence is not required. Restaurants and bars are restricted to take-out service. Retail outlets are restricted to the lesser of 15% of firecode capacity or 5 customers. All entertainment businesses and entities as well as personal and wellness services must close. See Government of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201211114009/https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=75859ADEA5D5E-045D-2386-0CB140C175A800DD

Effective 14 December, publicly-funded elementary and secondary schools in the Province of Saskatchewan switched to online learning until at least 11 January. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214232830/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-public-schools-in-regina-switch-to-remote-learning-as-covid-19-cases/

Effective 14 December, the Province of Ontario issued the following orders for the Windsor-Essex region (neighbouring Detroit, Michigan) and York region (suburban Toronto): retail stores must close for indoor shopping except those that sell groceries, drugs or hardware, which must respect a 50-per-cent capacity limit; restaurants restricted to takeout or delivery; gyms and hair salons must close. This order brings these regions in line with Toronto and the suburban Peel region. The York region member of the provincial Parliament expressed her disagreement with how the order applies to the retail sector. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219193748/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-moves-two-more-regions-into-lockdown-in-bid-to-contain-covid/

On 14 December, Ontario began vaccinating health care workers in Toronto and Quebec vaccinated workers and residents at long-term care facilities in Montreal and Quebec City. Other provinces are expected to start targeted vaccinations of high-risk groups later this week. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216165500/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-canada-administers-its-first-covid-19-vaccine-shots/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214190242/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-personal-support-worker-first-person-in-canada-to-receive-dose/

A:    On 15 December, British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan began vaccinating front-line health care workers.  See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219203531/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-western-canada-long-complex-job-of-covid-19-vaccinations-begins/

A:    On 16 December, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Prince Edward Island, and Manitoba began vaccinating front-line health care workers.  See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219202229/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-manitoba-three-atlantic-provinces-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-today/

Effective 17 December, the Province of Saskatchewan restricted outdoor gatherings to 10 people and indoor gatherings to immediate household members. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219200259/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-saskatchewan-bans-household-visits-will-limit-retail-capacity-starting/?+First+Canadians+vaccinated+against+COVID-19+=&cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 17 December, Statistics Canada released data showing that a record high 1.2 million Canadians received Employment Insurance (EI) benefits for unemployment in October. Together with self-employed Canada Recovery Benefit (CRB) recipients and other CRB recipients not eligible for EI, over 2 million Canadians (or over 10% of the pre-pandemic labour force) were receiving a job-related income support benefit from the federal government in October.   See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221195204/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/article-canadians-on-ei-surges-to-record-in-october-after-cerb-transfer/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

Although not as restrictive as in some provinces, effective 19 December, the Province of Saskatchewan ordered casinos and other gaming houses to close and restricted personal care service establishments such as hair salons to 50 per cent capacity. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219200259/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-saskatchewan-bans-household-visits-will-limit-retail-capacity-starting/?+First+Canadians+vaccinated+against+COVID-19+=&cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 19 December, the Canadian Press news service reported that the Province of New Brunswick began vaccinations starting with front-line health care workers and long-term care residents. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221203858/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-updates-dec-19-vaccinations-now-underway-in-all-provinces/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

Effective 20 December, the federal Minister of Finance “announced that the government has concluded the necessary regulatory changes to raise the maximum (Canada Emergency) Wage Subsidy rate to 75 per cent” until 13 March 2021. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221151917/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/12/government-announces-wage-subsidy-rate-increase-to-75-per-cent.html

Effective 21 December, the Province of Ontario issued the following orders for the Hamilton region (west of Toronto): retail stores must close for indoor shopping except those that sell groceries, drugs or hardware, which must respect a 50-per-cent capacity limit; restaurants restricted to takeout or delivery; gyms and hair salons must close. This order brings Hamilton in line with the City of Toronto and suburban regions as well as Windsor-Essex (neighbouring Detroit). See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221203858/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-updates-dec-19-vaccinations-now-underway-in-all-provinces/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 22 December, the Globe and Mail newspaper reported on lockdown resistance protests in different regions of Canada. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102131027/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/alberta/article-five-charged-in-calgary-as-police-take-more-aggressive-approach-to/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 23 December, Health Canada authorized use of the Moderna vaccine to immunize against covid-19. Delivery and distribution expected before year-end. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102132802/https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/74621a-eng.php

On 23 December, the Globe and Mail newspaper reported on covid-19 outbreaks in retirement homes (where residents are better able to care for themselves than residents of long-term care homes) with problems attributed to less stringent rules governing retirement homes. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102134423/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-alarm-raised-over-coronavirus-surge-in-retirement-homes/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 28 December, Andre Picard, health reporter at the Globe and Mail newspaper, commented on what he viewed as slow progress delivering vaccinations in Canada. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102220132/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-didnt-take-a-holiday-and-the-vaccine-rollout-should-not-have/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 29 December, the Globe and Mail newspaper reported on slow implementation of the federal government’s new Highly Affected Sectors Credit Availability Program to help businesses in tourism, hospitality, air travel and entertainment with fully government-guaranteed financing. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102225155/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-struggling-sectors-still-waiting-for-promised-relief-from-federal/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 29 December, Canadian Press news service reported on plans in several provinces to accelerate vaccinations. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102222357/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-nearly-4500-new-covid-19-cases-over-two-days/

A, C:    On 30 December, vaccinations began in remote indigenous communities in British Columbia (BC). Members of three groups -- long-term care residents, frontline workers, remote indigenous community residents -- have now been vaccinated somewhere in Canada. Vaccinations are expected to start soon in indigenous communities in other provinces. However, to my knowledge, there is no province that has vaccinated members of more than 2 groups at this time. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website and Province of BC website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210103010814/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-vaccine-rollout-picks-up-speed-in-first-nations-across-canada/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162416/http://www.bccdc.ca/health-info/diseases-conditions/covid-19/covid-19-vaccine/bcs-plan-for-vaccine-distribution

On 4 January, Quebec Minister of Health Christian Dubé tweeted “To bring down cases, we need your co-operation for the tracing done by public health” indicating that contact tracing may not be as timely and comprehensive in practice as earlier in the crisis. See Global news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210107191838/https://globalnews.ca/news/7553481/quebec-coronavirus-covid-19-jan-4-2021/

As of 4 January 2021, 11:18AM EST, according to the Canadian Television (CTV) News covid-19 vaccine tracker, 121,295 Canadians or 0.3% of the national population have received vaccinations. See CTV News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165037/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

On 5 January, Leger, a well-known Canadian public opinion research and polling firm, released a survey showing that 48% of respondents in a sample designed to be representative of Canada’s population ignored public health advice to stay home over the holidays and participated in at least one gathering with participants from outside the household. See Leger website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106200207/https://leger360.com/surveys/legers-north-american-tracker-january-5-2021/

On 5 January, Alberta Health reported employing 1,250 contact tracers at the end of 2020, short of their announced target of 1,600. Local CTV news reporters speculate that the shortfall in hiring of tracers has contributed to the fact that “59% of the province’s COVID-19 cases come from unknown origins”. See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210107192656/https://calgary.ctvnews.ca/yardsticks-always-being-moved-alberta-fails-to-meet-its-2020-target-for-contact-tracers-1.5255966

Effective 6 January, the Office of Premier Blaine Higgs announced that “the entire province of New Brunswick will move to the Orange level... Public Health recommended the move due to the doubling of cases in less than six days … as well as reports of situations where some individuals were not complying with public health measures.” To comply with orange alert rules requiring 1m distancing on public transit, city transit services reduced bus seating capacity to 50% or 15-20 passengers on each bus.     See New Brunswick government websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110192430/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2021.01.0007.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110205043/https://www.saintjohn.ca/news-and-service-updates/saint-john-transit-seating-capacity-reduced-by-covid-19-orange-phase  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110203956/https://www.fredericton.ca/en/transit

In the 8 January Globe and Mail print edition, western Canadian affairs columnist Gary Mason concludes that “in the worst-hit provinces in this country, such as Quebec, Ontario and Alberta, contact tracers have been overwhelmed by the sheer number of cases”. Mason’s conclusion is impressionistic without much in the way of data, but is consistent with other recent reports about contact tracing backlogs. See article on Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108135121/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-canadas-overwhelmed-contact-tracing-efforts-have-been-a-gross-failure/

A, C:    As of 8 January 10:30AM EST, according to the CTV News covid-19 vaccine tracker, 231,807 Canadians have received a covid-19 vaccination or 0.6% of the national population. See CTV News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106182429/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

Effective 9 January, the government of Quebec imposed a province-wide curfew in place between 8pm and 5am. Being out during those hours is prohibited without a specifically exempted reason -- e.g., travelling to and from essential work, owners walking a dog within a 1 km radius of home. Curfew rules will be in place until 8 Feburary at least. See government of Quebec website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210112081748/https://www.quebec.ca/premier-ministre/actualites/detail/le-premier-ministre-francois-legault-annonce-de-nouvelles-mesures-sanitaires-pour-controler-la-deuxi/

Effective 11 January, the first day of winter term class at most province of Ontario universities and colleges, post-secondary institutions move all classes online (with limited exceptions for small medical school applied sessions, etc.) in anticipation of the the provincial government’s signalled-well-in-advance decision to raise Ontario’s covid-19 alert status to the emergency level effective 14 January. Elementary and secondary schools had moved online when classes resumed on 4 January. With all education levels now online in Ontario, Canada’s most populous province, national code for Canada moved to 3T. See government of Ontario website archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114204552/https://www.ontario.ca/page/covid-19-provincewide-shutdown  ***Note edited to reflect that the closing of this univeristy is at the discretion of the university rather than due to government policy. Therefore, it is not reflected in the coding; however, useful to understand the context for Canadian school closures. https://web.archive.org/web/20210109022315/https://www.uwo.ca/coronavirus/presidents-updates/

A, C:    As of 11 January 10:21AM EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, 328,797 Canadians have received a covid-19 vaccination or just under 0.9% of the national population. (Another unofficial vaccine tracker website shows a slightly smaller national count. It is possible that vaccine tracker websites are not reporting up-to-date information in all provinces.) See covid19tracker.ca and CTV News websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111152357/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111145425/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

Limited evidence of household level debt and contract relief.    For instance, Ontario has temporarily banned evictions during lockdown:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210130120222/https://globalnews.ca/news/7575951/ontario-pauses-enforcement-residential-evictions-coronavirus/    Mortgage deferrals information from national government:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201216153510/https://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/finance-and-investing/mortgage-loan-insurance/the-resource/covid19-understanding-mortgage-payment-deferral    ***recoded as past coding, while still at a 1, used measures for businesses not households/individuals as evidence

On 14 January 2021, the Government of Quebec announced that, if vaccine supply is insufficient, the second vaccination dose will be delayed for up to 90 days in order to maximize first doses to members of high-risk groups. The Government of Canada’s Deputy Chief Public Health Officer “noted … that there is no data to support extending the interval past 42 days. However, he … suggested the ethical issues raised by a surge in cases and a resulting spike in hospitalizations and deaths could present an exceptional enough circumstance to justify it.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115140139/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-further-delaying-second-dose-of-covid-19-vaccines/

As of 15 January 10:21AM EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 450,242 Canadians (almost 1.2% of the national population) have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 24,939 Canadians (0.07%) are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115153920/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 18 January 11:06AM CST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 557,237 Canadians [almost 1.5% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 31,199 [0.08%] Canadians are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118183916/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html
New Brunswick reduces bus capacity 9 passangers per bus.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129204857/https://twitter.com/ThinkTransitSJ/status/1351617181642072065

A.C: On 19 January 2021, the Globe and Mail newspaper updated its “EXPLAINER: The federal and provincial rollout plans so far” which contains a clear explanation illustrated with charts on how the federal and provincial governments are working together and sharing responsibility to vaccinate Canadians. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126030320/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/

On 20 January 2021, Indigenous Services Canada announced: “The rollout of the vaccines to many First Nations, Inuit, and Métis communities has started. Vaccine administration continues within communities, thanks to the commitment of Indigenous leadership and health experts, and federal, provincial, Indigenous collaboration, including on logistics and data sharing. To date vaccination has begun in 169 communities for First Nations or Inuit in all provinces and territories except Nova Scotia and PEI.” Covid vaccinations (Pfizer and Moderna) in Canada are being administered to 3 groups -- A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or other health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126020941/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/01/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126024649/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-older-at-risk-federal-inmates-to-receive-shot-sparking-criticism-from/

On 23 January 2021, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada  repeated advice about “wearing a face mask as appropriate (including in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household)”. Most provinces have imposed such a requirement. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125231259/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/digital-resources.html

On 25 January 2021, elementary and secondary students in some regions of the province of Ontario returned to school. However, schools in the Cities of Toronto and Hamilton as well as the regions of Windsor-Essex (bordering Detroit), Peel and York (suburban Toronto) continue to conduct classes online until at least 10 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. See Government of Ontario and cp24 tv news websites,  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122104517if_/https://news.ontario.ca/en/statement/60033/over-100000-ontario-students-return-to-class-beginning-next-week   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125204416/https://www.cp24.com/news/students-return-to-in-class-instruction-in-seven-regions-of-province-today-1.5280563

On 25 January 2021, the government of Quebec published an updated list of businesses required to close and essential businesses allowed to operate under restricted rules. Quebec may have the most restrictive provincial policy in place now. Ontario has also closed and/or restricted business operations. Ontario and Quebec are the two most populous provinces See Government of Quebec website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125205800/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/list-commercial-enterprises/

On 25 January 2021, the City of Toronto (most populous in Canada) continues to conform with the “Province-wide (Ontario) declaration of emergency …(by) extending the cancellation of City-led and City-permitted outdoor special events through March 31”. Similar policies are in place in Quebec and other provinces. See City of Toronto website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210125211052/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-latest-city-of-toronto-news/affected-city-services/?accordion=events  ***Updated to also include Quebec - "Activities organized in a public place Prohibited, except for places of worship (maximum of 10 people in attendance) and funerals (a maximum of 25 people excluding the staff of the funeral establishment and volunteers inside or outside the building. Keeping an attendance register is mandatory). Moreover, no food or alcohol can be served."  http://web.archive.org/web/20210129173941/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/confinement-in-quebec/

On 25 January 2021, the government of Quebec clarified that its rule limiting regular religious observance gatherings to 10 persons applies to the entire building, not each room. Other than religious settings: “Indoor or outdoor private gatherings (p)rohibited.” Quebec may have the most restrictive provincial policy in place now. Other provinces have also restricted indoor and outdoor gatherings to a maximum of 10 persons. See Government of Quebec and Montreal Gazette newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125212921/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/confinement-in-quebec/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213115/https://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/quebec-flip-flops-on-gatherings-in-places-of-worship-for-third-time-in-48-hours

Municipal public transit in the province of New Brunswick reduced to 50% seating capacity. See CAN-NB. ***edited to add link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210129205247/https://twitter.com/ThinkTransitSJ/

As of 25 January 2021, the government of Quebec continues to impose a curfew between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m except for travel to and from an essential workplace and walking a dog. No other province has a curfew. See government of Quebec website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125212921/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/confinement-in-quebec/

As of January 25 2021, the 4 Atlantic provinces continue to require 14-day quarantine requirements on Canadians entering from another province (including other Atlantic provinces; Atlantic bubble suspended) as well as restrictions on "non-essential" travel into these provinces by non-residents. For examples, see CAN-NB and CAN_NL.   See New Brunswick website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130111953/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/travel.html  ***note updated to include New Brunswick website link

As of 25 January 2021, the government of Canada’s rules remain in place restricting non-Canadians from entering Canada except to perform “essential” work or to visit a family member who is a Canadian citizen. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114193357/https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/coronavirus-covid19/travel-restrictions-exemptions.html

E1 = 2A  As of 25 January 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In addition, Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians have been enhanced in many circumstances. See government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125223626/https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/benefits/recovery-benefit.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201124235654/https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/benefits/recovery-benefit/crb-statistics.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125224852/https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/ei/notice-covid-19.html

As of 25 January 2021, the government of Canada continues to provide online information resources on covid-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125231259/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/digital-resources.html

As of 25 January 2021, the government of Canada’s “Pan-Canadian COVID-19 Testing and Screening Guidance: Technical guidance and implementation plan”   continues to apply. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125231908/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-health-products/covid19-industry/medical-devices/testing/pan-canadian-guidance.html

On 25 January 2021, the Canadian Medical Association (CMA) called for “redoubling our efforts in effective … contact tracing”. This indicates that previously reported problems keeping contact tracing on pace with higher case numbers remain an issue. See CMA newswire, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125233051/https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/one-year-since-first-canadian-covid-19-case-the-cma-calls-for-a-clear-and-focused-plan-ahead-876909120.html

As of 25 January 1:05 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 733,500 Canadians [1.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 96,537 [0.25%] of Canadians are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124221629/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 25 January 2021, the government of Canada’s “Interim guidance: Care of residents in long term care homes during the COVID-19 pandemic” continues to apply. Some provinces -- e.g., British Columbia -- have implemented strict measures to protect long-term care residents. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125234806/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/guidance-documents/residents-long-term-care-homes-covid-19.html

In a 27 January 2021 report, the Globe and Mail, Canada’s only newspaper with a national readership, reported on recent contact tracing problems in a region in the province of Ontario north of Toronto with an outbreak of cases attributed to the “British variant”. The regional public health officer “reached out to other public-health units in Ontario for assistance with contact tracing. Three have stepped up … sending a total of nine staff to help with contact tracing...Without help from the other regions, Dr. Gardner said his health unit did not have the resources to reach contacts within 24 hours.” However, redeployment of contact tracers from low-case to high-case regions is a positive initiative. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210128135316/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-cases-keep-climbing-after-ontario-long-term-care-home-struck/

In a 28 January 2021 Canadian Press news service report, more coverage of whether border controls are strict enough to encourage enough Canadians to heed public health advice to limit international travel to essential trips. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210128135746/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-holiday-season-vacations-coincide-with-rise-in-covid-19-travel-related-2/

C1 = 3T  In the 29 January 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, there was a report on the province of Ontario’s decision to return elementary and secondary students in some regions (Ottawa, southeastern Ontario including Kingston, southwestern Ontario including London) to in-class learning at school from online classes at home. However, schools in the Cities of Toronto and Hamilton as well as the regions of Windsor-Essex (bordering Detroit), Peel and York (suburban Toronto) continue to conduct classes online until at least 10 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129181047/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-modelling-projects-continued-drop-in-cases-if-restrictions/

In the 29 January 2021 print editions of English-language Canadian newspapers, a Canadian Press report quoted Quebec Premier Francois Legault’s warning that “the majority of measures will remain … such as closing non-essential businesses”. Quebec continues to enforce the most restrictive policy among Canada’s provinces and territories. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129153654/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-number-of-deaths-in-quebec-jumped-10-per-cent-in-2020-due-to-covid-19/

C3 = 3T  On 29 January 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force: “Indoor organized events … are not permitted...Meeting and event spaces are closed...Concert venues, theatres and cinemas are not permitted to open for any purpose.” The Province of Quebec and other provinces have imposed similar rules. See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202172433/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/covid-19-guidance-indoor-outdoor-events/

On 29 January 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force:  " (1) Subject to sections 2 to 4, no person shall attend, (a)  an organized public event that is held indoors; (b)  a social gathering that is held indoors, including a social gathering associated with a gathering described in clause (d); (c)  an organized public event or social gathering of more than 5 people that is held outdoors, including a social gathering associated with a gathering described in clause (d); or (d)  a gathering of more than 10 people for the purposes of a wedding, a funeral or a religious service, rite or ceremony"  Link not archiving: https://www.ontario.ca/laws/regulation/200082/v34  ***Note updated to include bylaw link and full text on gatherings; link to Toronto website deleted as it was from November and allowed up to 10 people at outdoor events, compared to Ontario bylaw 82/20 which now only allows for 5

On 29 January 2021, the Province of New Brunswick continues to restrict bus transit to 50% seating capacity. See Saint John Transit twitter, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129192512/https://twitter.com/ThinkTransitSJ/

In the 29 January 2021 print editions of English-language Canadian newspapers, a Canadian Press report quoted Quebec Premier Francois Legault’s warning that “the majority of measures will remain … Legault singled out the province’s 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew as a measure that is “working well,” suggesting that it was likely to be among the rules that is extended..” Quebec continues to be the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129153654/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-number-of-deaths-in-quebec-jumped-10-per-cent-in-2020-due-to-covid-19/

29 January was the first full day of effect in 2021 for the province of Manitoba’s requirement: “Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” Manitoba imposed a similar rule during 2020 and then relaxed the requirements gradually. The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, that now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129195407/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 29 January 2021, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced an agreement with Canadian airlines to suspend flights to Mexican and Carribean destinations effective 31 January through 30 April. ‘In the coming weeks the federal government will also introduce mandatory COVID-19 testing upon arrival at airports, and this will be on top of the pre-boarding requirement for a negative COVID-19 test, Mr. Trudeau said. Following the second test, travellers will have to wait three days at a designated hotel for their test result. Mr. Trudeau said the hotel stays will cost travellers more than $2,000. If the traveller’s second test is negative, they will be able to complete their 14-day quarantine at home “under significantly increased surveillance and enforcement.”’ These measures are intended to encourage Canadians to heed public health advice against non-essential international travel. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129180239/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-federal-government-airlines-agree-to-halt-flights-to-caribbean-mexico/

E1 = 2A  As of 29 January 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In addition, Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians have been enhanced in many circumstances. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126183447/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

As of 29 January 2021, the government of Canada continues to provide: “Digital tools to help Canadians access services and get information on COVID-19”. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129202310/https://www.canada.ca/en/government/system/digital-government/digital-government-response-to-covid-19.html

H2 = 2G  As of 29 January 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are similar. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118232215/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 29 January 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask or face covering when you're in public and you might come into close contact with others; you're in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. 3T pending review of whether all provinces and territories require masks in outdoor public spaces. See Government of Canada website, archived: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  ***Review note: confirmed via subnational data that some provinces (e.g. BC) coded as 2G for masks, meaning 3T at national level still accurate

As of 29 January 10:25 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 82.5% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 829,385 Canadians [almost 2.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 96,857 Canadians [0.25%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” Note that previous estimates of the number of Canadians fully vaccinated were incorrect due to a data reporting error by one of the provinces. Delays in vaccine delivery to Canada have resulted in first-does vaccinations being halted in the province of Alberta. In most other provinces and territories, vaccine supply is sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129155032/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129163115/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/covid-update-deena-hinshaw-alberta-1.5891450

As of 29 January 2021, the province of British Columbia (BC) continues to have the strongest protections in Canada for residents of long-term care (LTC) homes. Since, April 2020 BC requires that long-term care staff work at one designated facility rather than work part-time at two or more facilities. Other provinces restrict visitors and Ontario now has a similar staffing rule (but may not have provided the financial resources for implementation). Even with these rules, BC has also experienced serious covid outbreaks in LTCs. See Province of British Columbia website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201231021709/http://www.bccdc.ca/Health-Info-Site/Documents/COVID19_LongTermCareAssistedLiving.pdf

In a 1 February Globe and Mail newspaper article, the reporter comments: “The Simcoe Muskoka health unit is revamping its contact tracing systems instead of relying on people who test positive for COVID-19 to track down their contacts. It is one of many regions in Canada that have significantly scaled back identifying, managing and assessing those who have been exposed because they could no longer keep up with the pace of new infections.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205202621/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-variant-in-barrie-outbreak-upends-conventional-wisdom-of/

In the 4 February 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, there was a report on the province of Ontario’s decision to return elementary and secondary students in the regions of Windsor-Essex (bordering Detroit), Hamilton, Halton and Durham (suburban Toronto) to in-class learning at school on 8 February from online classes at home. However, schools in Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York continue to conduct classes online until 16 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210204192310/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-most-ontario-schools-will-return-to-in-class-learning-on-monday/

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Ontario (the most populous in Canada) continues to enforce closures and restrictions on non-essential businesses as do Quebec, New Brunswick and other jurisdictions. Some provinces have started a gradual reopening. See GOVERNment of Ontario website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201191314/https://www.ontario.ca/page/enhancing-public-health-and-workplace-safety-measures-provincewide-shutdown  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205140421/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-number-of-covid-19-cases-in-first-nations-communities-has-dropped-to/

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force: “A Province-wide declaration of emergency is in effect. Stay home except for essential reasons. … Indoor organized events … are not permitted...Meeting and event spaces are closed...Concert venues, theatres and cinemas are not permitted to open for any purpose.” Other provinces (but not all) have imposed similar rules. See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129185219/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/covid-19-guidance-indoor-outdoor-events/

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force: “Indoor … social gatherings are not permitted, except with members of the same household. Outdoor gatherings are permitted with 5 people or less with physical distancing.” Limits are higher in other provinces at lower covid alert levels -- e.g., Newfoundland and Labrador. See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129185219/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/covid-19-guidance-indoor-outdoor-events/

On 5 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment...Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...Travellers entering Canada must, during your 14-day period while in quarantine or isolation, stay in a hotel while waiting a negative result of their molecular test.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205151123/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

As of 5 February 1:30 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 89.1% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 883,648 Canadians [2.3% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 150,807 Canadians [almost 0.4%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has resulted in a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010943/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205162839/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/gov

Businesses are now allowed to host events and activities. In a 10 February Globe and Mail newspaper article, the City of Hamilton’s Medical Officer of Health laments that the province of Ontario’s “reopening plans are emerging just as her staff have recovered their ability to keep up with the task of tracing all the contacts of confirmed cases”. Since other regions have higher daily case per capita counts than Hamilton, it is probable that contact tracing delays are continuing in other parts of Canada. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211133106/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-medical-officers-in-some-covid-19-hot-spots-push-back-against-ontarios/

Effective 11 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador “Chief Medical Officer of Health has issued a modified special measures order for the St. John’s metro area: Schools and post-secondary educational institutions are closed.” As noted on 4 February 2021 schools in Canada’s largest city Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York continue to conduct classes online until 16 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. In the rest of Canada, elementary and secondary schools are open. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210204192310/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-most-ontario-schools-will-return-to-in-class-learning-on-monday/

Effective 11 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador “Chief Medical Officer of Health has issued a modified special measures order for the St. John’s metro area: Gym and fitness facilities, yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, arenas, dance studios and performance spaces are closed. Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service, but can offer online/telephone sales with delivery or curbside pick-up options. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed. Restaurants are closed for in-person dining. Take-out, delivery and drive-thru options are permitted. Bars, lounges, bingo halls and cinemas are closed.” Other provinces have started or announced intentions to begin a gradual reopening. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211161415/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/editorials/article-will-doug-fords-reopening-plan-be-a-booster-shot-for-the-pandemic/
