On 19 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force in the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city): “Indoor … social gatherings are not permitted, except with members of the same household. Outdoor gatherings are permitted with 5 people or less with physical distancing.” The same limit applies in Newfoundland and Labrador at alert level 5. Limits are higher in other provinces at lower covid alert levels -- e.g., Nova Scotia. See City of Toronto,  Government of Newfoundland and Labrador, and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219153328/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/covid-19-guidance-indoor-outdoor-events/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208225300/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/nova-scotia-reports-one-new-case-of-covid-19-monday-restrictions-ease-1.5299957  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217214201/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/

On 19 February 2021, the Provinces of Newfoundland/Labrador (NL) and New Brunswick (NB) continue to restrict bus transit seating capacity. See Codiac (Moncton, NB region) and St. John’s NL transportation websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219155131/https://www.codiactranspo.ca/moncton-transport/codiac-transpos-response-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122110829/https://www.metrobus.com/html-default/bootstrap/pages/index.asp

On 19 February 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in southern Quebec and 9:30 pm to 5 am in less populated northern Quebec where covid cases per capita are lower. Quebec continues to be the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219164023/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-reports-669-new-covid-19-cases-and-20-additional-deaths/

On 19 February 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “As per the public health order, 14 days of self-isolation is required for people returning or coming to Manitoba from all jurisdictions. Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219164644/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 19 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment. If a traveller's entry is permitted, they'll be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days... Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...There are no exemptions from mandatory quarantine for travellers entering Canada.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219165800/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

As of 19 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In addition, Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians have been enhanced in many circumstances. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219180557/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

As of 19 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In addition, Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians have been enhanced in many circumstances. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219180557/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

As of 19 Febuary 2021, the government of Canada continues with a “national public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.”  See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212010028/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

As of 19 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are similar. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219181517/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 19 February 2021, there is not enough evidence to say that contact tracing is back to comprehensive in all regions of Canada. In a Globe and Mail newspaper opinion column, Dr. Brooks Fallis expressed dissatisfaction by urging provincial and territorial governments: “Focus contact tracing efforts on high-risk areas that continue to drive transmission and properly invest in local public health units so we can rapidly trace every contact.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217153210/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-canada-is-sleepwalking-into-a-third-wave-and-it-could-be-the-worst-one/

As of 19 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., British Columbia exempts elementary school students. See Government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184203/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213205449/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/covid-19-bc-school-guidelines-enhanced-health-and-safety-measures-announced-1.5899483

As of 19 February 11:12AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,007,878 Canadians [2.65% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 372,911 Canadians [almost 1%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past 4 weeks. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217180702/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184842/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 19 February 2021, the province of British Columbia (BC) continues to have the strongest protections in Canada for residents of long-term care (LTC) homes. Since, April 2020 BC requires that long-term care staff work at one designated facility rather than work part-time at two or more facilities. As a result, a lower % of BC LTC homes have experienced covid outbreaks than has been the case in other provinces. Other provinces do restrict visitors. Newfoundland and Ontario have similar staffing rules. See Province of British Columbia and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212011449/http://www.bccdc.ca/Health-Info-Site/Documents/COVID19_LongTermCareAssistedLiving.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205051148/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/alberta/article-albertas-auditor-general-to-review-provinces-covid-19-response-in/

On 24 February 2021, the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city) announced “extending the cancellation of in-person City-led and City-permitted major outdoor events to July 1, including Canada Day parades, festivals and fireworks. Today’s announcement includes festivals and other large, in-person gatherings held at outdoor sites managed by the City or other public locations, such as roads, parks and civic squares.” Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., Nova Scotia allowing public events with rules. See City of Toronto websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225045219/https://www.toronto.ca/news/city-of-toronto-extends-cancellation-of-in-person-major-events-to-july-1/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210218051016/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/docs/Events-theatres-and-venues-COVID-19-prevention-guidelines.pdf

On 24 february 2021, in the territory of Nunavut, a 10 pm to 6 am curfew took effect in Arviat (population 2,800). The entire province of Quebec remains under curfew with times varying by region. See Toronto Star website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302213853/https://www.thestar.com/politics/2021/03/02/mayor-in-nunavut-hopes-curfew-order-bylaw-patrol-will-bring-drop-in-covid-19-cases.html

On 25 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador remains at alert level 5: “Gym and fitness facilities are closed, including yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, and arenas. Dance studios and performance spaces are closed...Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed.” Non-essential businesses remain closed in Canada’s largest city Toronto, a suburban Toronto region and a northern Ontario region “until March 8”. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219150436/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225163539/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-975-new-covid-19-cases-and-12-additional-deaths/

Having family or friends who are not members of your household in your home for a social visit is prohibited under provincial orders... social gatherings are not permitted, except with members of the same household. On 25 February 2021, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada warned: “Any easing of public health measures must be done slowly with enhanced testing, screening, and genomic analysis to detect variants of concern. In particular, there must be sufficient contact tracing capacity”. This concern suggests that contact tracing may not be comprehensive in all regions of Canada. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225201518/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/02/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-february-25-2021.html

As of 25 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., British Columbia exempts elementary school students at their desks. See Government of Canada and Globe newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224134806/http://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225202506/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-covid-19-variant-in-schools-means-its-time-for-all-students-in-bc-to/

On 26 February 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador at alert level 5, “the Chief Medical Officer of Health and the Provincial Government, advised that all schools would be moving to Scenario 3 - online instruction. This will continue until at least Friday, February 26, as part of province-wide efforts to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19.” See Newfoundland and Labrador English School District website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220172254/https://www.nlesd.ca/families/covid19-2021.jsp

As of 26 February 10:21AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,231,835 Canadians [3.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 497,318 Canadians [1.3%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past month. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations are starting or are about to start for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. On 26 Feb. 2021, Health Canada authorized the AstraZeneca vaccine (including the version from the Serum Institute of India) for use in Canada for those aged 18 and up. See CTV news, Globe newspaper, and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224122201/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226155631/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-health-canada-approves-astrazenecas-covid-19-vaccine-for-people-over/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160443/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-with-a-mass-expansion-of-the-covid-19-vaccine-program-just-weeks-away/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160132/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities2.html

As of 26 February 2021, the province of British Columbia (BC) continues to have strong protections in Canada for residents of long-term care (LTC) homes. Since, April 2020 BC requires that long-term care staff work at one designated facility rather than work part-time at two or more facilities. Newfoundland and Labrador (NL) has similar rules to BC for visitors as well as restricting staff to working at one facility. Other provinces have added rules and restrictions on visitors to protect LTC residents and staff, but protections do not meet the “3 = extensive” standard in some provinces . See Provinces of BC and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219193019/http://www.bccdc.ca/Health-Info-Site/Documents/COVID19_LongTermCareAssistedLiving.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219150436/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/

A,B,C: On 1 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommended against using the AstraZenec-Oxford vaccine in people aged 65 and older, although Health Canada has authorized it to be used in adults of all ages”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans. See CBC news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308155125/https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/astra-zeneca-vaccine-naci-age-1.5932347

A,B,C: On 3 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommends that in the context of limited COVID-19 vaccine supply, jurisdictions should maximize the number of individuals benefiting from the first dose of vaccine by extending the interval for the second dose of vaccine to four months”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans to include the four-month interval. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308154413/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/rapid-response-extended-dose-intervals-covid-19-vaccines-early-rollout-population-protection.html

A,B,C: On 5 March 2021, “Health Canada authorized the COVID-19 vaccine manufactured by Janssen Inc. [owned by Johnson & Johnson]…. for use in people over 18 years of age”. “Health Canada has now approved four distinct COVID-19 vaccines, with the others being from Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Oxford-AstraZeneca.” The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being administered to Canadians. Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines may not have been administered yet. The first shipment to Canada arrived 3rd March. See CBC news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305211028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/naci-interval-advice-change-four-months-1.5934563  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305203353/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2021/03/health-canada-authorizes-janssen-covid-19-vaccine.html

On 8 march 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), the Avalon Peninsula (St. John’s capital region) remains at alert level 5: “up to and including Friday, March 12 ...Online Instruction”. In the province of Ontario: “Schools in the City of Thunder Bay, and surrounding municipalities, will be closed for in-person learning starting Monday, March 1, 2021 for a period of at least 2 weeks.” See NL English School District and Thunder Bay District Health Unit websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301194915/https://www.nlesd.ca/families/covid19-2021.jsp  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307112853/https://www.tbdhu.com/currentlevel

Dance studios and performance spaces are closed...Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. On 8 march 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in Montreal (largest city) and surrounding regions, while moving more regions to the 9:30 pm to 5 am curfew already in force in northern and western Quebec regions. Quebec continues to be the only province in Canada with a curfew. In the territory of Nunavut, the 10 pm to 6 am curfew in force in Arviat (population 2,800) is due to be lifted 8 March. See CTV news and Toronto Star websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307173506/https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/all-of-quebec-to-become-orange-zone-on-march-8-except-for-montreal-and-surrounding-areas-1.5332367  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302213853/https://www.thestar.com/politics/2021/03/02/mayor-in-nunavut-hopes-curfew-order-bylaw-patrol-will-bring-drop-in-covid-19-cases.html

On 8 march 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “As per the public health order, 14 days of self-isolation is required for people returning or coming to Manitoba from all jurisdictions. Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which also apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic travel now applies only between the provinces of Nova Scotia (NS) and Prince Edward Island. See Provinces of Manitoba and NS websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308141157/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227195137/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/

On 8 march 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise that “the COVID-19 pandemic restricts travel to Canada ... There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment. If a traveller's entry is permitted, they'll be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days...There are no exemptions from mandatory quarantine for travellers entering Canada.” See government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210304121640/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308142827/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions

As of 8 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In addition, Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians have been enhanced in many circumstances. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308143213/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

As of 8 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to provide support for businesses seeking commercial rent relief and low-interest loans. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308143213/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

As of 8 march 2021, the government of Canada continues with a “national public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.”See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308143555/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

As of 3 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are broadly similar. Testing has recently been extended to asymptomatic individuals in “outbreak” regions in Atlantic Canada, but asymptomatic testing remains the exception, not the rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308144053/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

In the 8 march 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, the president of the Ontario Hospital Association was quoted by Canadian Press: “When the pandemic’s over, we have to have a very good look at how we can strengthen our capability with other preventative measures such as testing and tracing.” This concern provides further evidence that contact tracing may not be comprehensively keeping up with case volumes in all regions of Canada. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308144931/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-toronto-has-had-some-of-the-longest-covid-19-business-closures-in/

As of 8 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., some provinces exempt elementary school students at their desks (in some regions). See Government of Canada and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308145352/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308150044/https://bc.ctvnews.ca/teachers-ask-elementary-school-kids-in-other-provinces-have-to-wear-masks-so-why-not-in-b-c-1.5325795

As of 8 March 2021 1:30PM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1864745 Canadians [4.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 567,954 Canadians [almost 1.5%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations have started for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. According to Canada’s Minister of Indigenous Services, “more than 127,000 COVID-19 vaccine doses have been administered in more than 480 First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities... approximately 40% of the indigenous population in First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities having received at least one dose.”  See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308184423/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308160146/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities.html

As of march 2021, the province of British Columbia (BC) continues to have strong protections for residents of long-term care (LTC) homes. Since, April 2020 BC requires that long-term care staff work at one designated facility rather than work part-time at two or more facilities. Other provinces have added rules and restrictions on visits to protect LTC residents and staff, but protections do not meet the “3 = extensive” standard in all provinces . See Provinces of BC website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308151120/http://www.bccdc.ca/Health-Info-Site/Documents/COVID19_LongTermCareAssistedLiving.pdf

On 11 March 2021, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada repeated her warning: “Any easing of public health measures must be done slowly with enhanced testing, screening, and genomic analysis to detect variants of concern. In particular, there must be sufficient contact tracing capacity”. This concern suggests that contact tracing may not be comprehensive in all regions of Canada. However, it should also be noted that contact tracing backlogs in Alberta that emerged in late 2020 were reported solved in Feb. 2021 with more tracers deployed. See Government of Canada and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312194306/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/03/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-march-11-2021.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312192758/https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/alberta-caught-up-on-contact-tracing-backlog-ahs-1.5293271

On 12 march 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), all schools on the Avalon Peninsula (St. John’s capital region) remain closed with students learning online. In the province of Ontario: “the Medical Officer of Health … is directing schools in the City of Thunder Bay and surrounding areas to extend the suspension of in-person learning until March 29, 2021”. See NL English School District and Thunder Bay District Health Unit websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312150040/https://www.nlesd.ca/about/news/index.jsp?story=All+K-9+Students+Return+to+In-Class+Instruction%2C+Most+High+Schools+Online&NewsCategory=3  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312150306/https://www.tbdhu.com/news/medical-officer-of-health-extends-suspension-of-person-learning

12 march 2021 is the last day in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL) when the Avalon Peninsula (St. John’s capital region) remains at alert level 5: “Gym and fitness facilities are closed, including yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, and arenas. Dance studios and performance spaces are closed...Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed.” On 13 March, the Avalon Peninsula will move to alert level 4 and some businesses will open with restrictions. In the rest of Canada, some “non-essential” businesses are open with restrictions (rules set by each province and territory). See Government of NL website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312151930/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0311n03/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312152003/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/

As of 12 march 2021, the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city) 24 Feb. 2021 announcement remains in effect “extending the cancellation of in-person City-led and City-permitted major outdoor events to July 1, including Canada Day parades, festivals and fireworks...festivals and other large, in-person gatherings held at outdoor sites managed by the City or other public locations, such as roads, parks and civic squares.” Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., Nova Scotia allowing public events with rules. See City of Toronto websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312152757/https://www.toronto.ca/news/city-of-toronto-extends-cancellation-of-in-person-major-events-to-july-1/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312153707/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/docs/Events-theatres-and-venues-COVID-19-prevention-guidelines.pdf

On 12 march 2021, in the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city): “Indoor organized events and social gatherings are not permitted, except with members of the same household. Outdoor gatherings are permitted with 10 people or less with physical distancing.” Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels -- e.g., Nova Scotia (NS). See City of Toronto and government of NS  websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312155100/https://www.toronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/9636-COVID-19-Indoor-Outdoor-Events-Gatherings.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312162912/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restrictions-and-guidance/

On 12 march 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity. See St. John’s and Cornerbrook, NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312163537/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312163850/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/

On 12 march 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in Montreal (largest city) and surrounding regions, while in the rest of the province there is a 9:30 pm to 5 am curfew. Quebec is the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. The curfew in Arviat, Nunavut ended the morning of 9 March. The Premier of Quebec hopes that continued vaccination progress will eventually allow for the curfew to be lifted. See CBC news and Toronto Star websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312164939/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/quebec-covid-19-restrictions-vaccination-1.5942755  https://web.archive.org/web/20210309203651/https://www.thestar.com/politics/2021/03/09/nunavut-community-of-arviat-loosens-covid-19-restrictions-wednesday.html

As of 12 march 2021, Newfoundland and Labrador (NL) continues to advise: “There are travel restrictions in place. You are only permitted entry into the province if your purpose of travel meets extenuating circumstances outlined by the Chief Medical Officer of Health. The following individuals are permitted entry to Newfoundland and Labrador: A resident of Newfoundland and Labrador or a resident of another Atlantic Province (Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island)...all residents of the Atlantic Bubble are required to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival to Newfoundland and Labrador; An essential worker; A resident of St. Pierre and Miquelon (French territorial islands near NL) requiring health care; and An individual who meets the [extenuating circumstances] criteria approved by the Chief Medical Officer of Health.  Those people who have been granted a travel exemption from Public Health and are coming to Newfoundland and Labrador from other Canadian provinces or territories are required to complete 14 days of self-isolation upon arrival in the province. This does not apply to rotational workers arriving from other areas of Canada who have opted for seven days of isolation with a negative COVID-19 test.” The 3 other Atlantic provinces as well as Manitoba impose quarantine requirements on out-of-province visitors See Province of NL website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312182341/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/individuals-and-households/travel-advice-2/

On 12 march 2021, the Prime Minister of Canada ‘did not rule out waiting until September or later to reopen the border, which has been closed since March 2020. “We will see what vaccinations look like, we will see what case counts look like. We will listen to experts ...” See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312181353/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/vaccine-and-case-counts-will-determine-when-border-opens-says-trudeau-1.5344805

As of 12 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. As of 12 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are broadly similar. Testing has recently been extended to asymptomatic individuals in “outbreak” regions in Atlantic Canada and to school children in Ontario, but asymptomatic testing remains the exception, not the rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312183614/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 12 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., some provinces exempt elementary school students at their desks. See Governments of Canada and British Columbia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312183925/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312184710/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/education-training/k-12/covid-19-safe-schools

As of 12 March 2021 12:50PM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 2,205,244 Canadians [5.8% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 589,048 Canadians [1.55%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of J&J shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312175918/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312180206/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities0.html

As of 12 march 2021, the province of British Columbia (BC) continues to have strong protections for residents of long-term care (LTC) homes. Since, April 2020 BC requires that long-term care staff work at one designated facility rather than work part-time at two or more facilities. Other provinces have added rules and restrictions on visits to protect LTC residents and staff, but protections do not meet the “3 = extensive” standard in all provinces . See Province of BC website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312190147/http://www.bccdc.ca/Health-Info-Site/Documents/COVID19_LongTermCareAssistedLiving.pdf

On 13 march 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL) relaxed the Avalon peninsula (St. John’s provincial capital region) to Alert Level 4 from 5.  “Retail stores, including those in shopping malls, can open at 50 per cent capacity. Personal service establishments can open in accordance with guidelines...Private health care clinics can reopen in accordance with guidelines.” In the three Maritime provinces (NS, NB, NL), businesses are open with relatively light restrictions. In the rest of Canada, some “non-essential” businesses are open with relatively tighter restrictions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210314174721/https://www.nlesd.ca/includes/files/news/doc/1615485546330.pdf

In a 15 March 2021 newspaper report, in the City of Toronto when “(a)sked where some of the cases [at a local school] may have originated, response [from the associate medical officer of health] was vague”. Contact tracing problems seem to be continuing at least in Toronto. Contact tracing backlogs in other jurisdictions that emerged in late 2020 appear to have been addressed. Until there is evidence that contact tracing is effective across Canada, “1” code maintained. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322135841/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/toronto/article-toronto-private-school-upper-canada-college-temporarily-closes-due-to/

On 17 march 2021, the Province of Quebec “pushed back the overnight curfew in Montreal and its surrounding regions to 9:30 p.m. from 8 p.m…[In] the rest of the province, … residents must still be inside by 9:30 p.m. [except in] three less populated regions, including the Gaspe Peninsula, the curfew will be entirely lifted.” Quebec is the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319224139/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-legault-expected-to-revise-covid-19-health-orders-today-as-quebec/

On 18 March 2021, Canada’s Public Safety Minister tweeted: “Non-essential travel restrictions with the United States have been extended until April 21st, 2021.” See government of Canada twitter, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322133732/https://twitter.com/BillBlair/status/1372531537686724614

On 22 march 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Ontario: “the Medical Officer of Health … is directing schools in the City of Thunder Bay and surrounding areas to extend the suspension of in-person learning until March 29, 2021” and in the “Sudbury, Espanola and Manitoulin areas … students … will learn remotely until further notice”. See Thunder Bay District Health Unit and Rainbow Schools District websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312150306/https://www.tbdhu.com/news/medical-officer-of-health-extends-suspension-of-person-learning  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312151257/https://www.rainbowschools.ca/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Letter-Parents-Move-to-Remote-Learning-March-11-21.pdf

On 22 march 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. No jurisdiction is in full lockdown with all “non-essential” businesses closed. In the three Maritime provinces (NS, NB, PEI), businesses are open with relatively light restrictions. Ontario’s rules for the City of Toronto (Canada’s most populous city) are representative of those jurisdictions maintaining stricter controls to cope with relatively high covid case counts: “Indoor dining, outdoor dining and patios are not permitted. Take-out, drive-through and delivery options remain available … All indoor gyms and recreational programs are closed … In-store shopping and shopping malls are permitted to open, subject to capacity limits. All hair salons, barber shops, nail salons and tattoo parlours are closed. Meeting and event spaces will remain closed. Casinos, bingo halls and other gaming establishments remain closed.” See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319174601/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/

Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., some provinces exempt elementary school students at their desks. See Government of Canada and Globe newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322140527/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319222147/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-western-canada-bc-teacher-workplace-injury-data-fuels-debate-over-mask/

As of 22 March 2021 5:50PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 3,409,857 Canadians [9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 632,489 Canadians [1.6%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education and emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, medical conditions), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322224218/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 22 march 2021, the province of British Columbia (BC) continues to protect residents and staff in long-term care (LTC) homes. Since, April 2020 BC requires that long-term care staff work at one designated facility rather than work part-time at two or more facilities. Other provinces have added rules and restrictions on visits to protect LTC residents and staff, but protections do not meet the “3 = extensive” standard in all provinces . See Province of BC website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322150959/http://www.bccdc.ca/health-professionals/clinical-resources/covid-19-care/clinical-care/long-term-care-facilities-assisted-living

In the 23 march 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, health reporter André Picard commented: “Canada is still averaging about 3,300 new COVID-19 cases every day. Where are all these people getting infected? We seem to have forgotten about basics such as contact tracing” This concern provides further evidence that contact tracing may not be comprehensively keeping up with case volumes in all regions of Canada. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210325124622/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-the-third-wave-of-the-pandemic-is-here-now-what/

On 24 March 2021, Health Canada updated the product monograph—or label—for the AstraZeneca and COVISHIELD COVID-19 vaccines to provide information on very rare reports of blood clots associated with low levels of blood platelets (i.e., thrombocytopenia) following immunization with the AstraZeneca vaccine...The Department has also issued guidance for healthcare professionals and vaccine recipients on the potential symptoms to monitor. Health Canada reassures Canadians that the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine continues to be safe and effective at protecting them against COVID-19 and encourages people to get immunized with any of the COVID-19 vaccines that are authorized in Canada.”  See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326174902/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2021/03/health-canada-issues-label-change-and-guidance-on-the-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine.html

On 25 March 2021, the Auditor General of Canada released a report on the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) and concluded: “PHAC did not always meet the targets it set to verify whether travellers subject to the mandatory 14-day quarantine upon entering Canada were following the quarantine orders...The Public Health Agency of Canada should improve its systems and processes for administering the nationwide mandatory quarantine during the COVID-19 pandemic, including the collection of contact information and follow-up to verify compliance.” This criticism does not appear strong enough to warrant adjusting the code down from the current “4=border closure” level. See Auditor General of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326174109/https://www.oag-bvg.gc.ca/internet/English/att__e_43789.html

***Updated to fix archived source On 26 march 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Ontario: “the Medical Officer of Health … is directing schools in the City of Thunder Bay and surrounding areas to extend the suspension of in-person learning until April 12, 2021” and in the Sudbury, Espanola and Manitoulin areas “ALL students will learn remotely until further notice”. At the post-secondary level across Canada, many institutions are delivering classes online.See Thunder Bay District Health Unit and Rainbow Schools District websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210327202957/https://www.tbdhu.com/news/medical-officer-of-health-extends-suspension-of-person-learning-0 https://web.archive.org/web/20210325212325/https://www.rainbowschools.ca/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Letter-Parents-Walden-Outbreak-Over-March-23-21-.pdf

On 26 march 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. No jurisdiction is in full lockdown with all “non-essential” businesses closed. In two Maritime provinces (NS, PEI), businesses are open with relatively light restrictions. Ontario’s rules for the City of Toronto (Canada’s most populous city) are representative of those jurisdictions maintaining stricter controls to cope with relatively high covid case counts: “Indoor dining, outdoor dining and patios are not permitted. Take-out, drive-through and delivery options remain available … All indoor gyms and recreational programs are closed … In-store shopping and shopping malls are permitted to open, subject to capacity limits. All hair salons, barber shops, nail salons and tattoo parlours are closed. Meeting and event spaces will remain closed. Casinos, bingo halls and other gaming establishments remain closed.”  See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210325212647/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/

As of 26 march 2021, the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city) 24 Feb. 2021 announcement remains in effect “extending the cancellation of in-person City-led and City-permitted major outdoor events to July 1, including Canada Day parades, festivals and fireworks...festivals and other large, in-person gatherings held at outdoor sites managed by the City or other public locations, such as roads, parks and civic squares.” Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., Maritime provinces allowing public events with rules. See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210325212912/https://www.toronto.ca/news/city-of-toronto-extends-cancellation-of-in-person-major-events-to-july-1/

26 march 2021 is the first full day that the province of New Brunswick (NB) placed the city of Edmundston and surrounding area back in the Red Alert level: “Social gatherings: Indoor – Your household bubble; Outdoor – 5 people or less with masks and physical distancing.” In the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), the Avalon peninsula (St. John’s capital and most populous city-region) remains at Alert Level 4: “You must stay within your household bubble whenever you are not at work or school... Gatherings at funerals, burials, weddings, religious and cultural ceremonies are limited to no more than 10 people, including the officiant.” Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See Governments of NB and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210325214654/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/news/news_release.2021.03.0235.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210325214408/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/alert-levels/red%20level.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210325214301/https://www.gov.nl.ca:443/covid-19/files/Summary-Table-of-COVID-19-Alert-Level-System-graphic.pdf

On 26 march 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. See St. John’s and Cornerbrook, NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326132349/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326132648/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/

As of 26 march 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce an overnight curfew 9:30 p.m. to 5 a.m. most of the province. Quebec is the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See montreal gazette newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326131820/https://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/coronavirus-whats-open-and-closed-in-montreal

As of 26 march 2021, Newfoundland and Labrador (NL) continues to advise: “There are travel restrictions in place. You are only permitted entry into the province if your purpose of travel meets extenuating circumstances outlined by the Chief Medical Officer of Health. The following individuals are permitted entry to Newfoundland and Labrador: A resident of Newfoundland and Labrador or a resident of another Atlantic Province (Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island)...all residents of the Atlantic Bubble are required to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival to Newfoundland and Labrador; An essential worker; A resident of St. Pierre and Miquelon (French territorial islands near NL) requiring health care; and An individual who meets the [extenuating circumstances] criteria approved by the Chief Medical Officer of Health.  Those people who have been granted a travel exemption from Public Health and are coming to Newfoundland and Labrador from other Canadian provinces or territories are required to complete 14 days of self-isolation upon arrival in the province.” The 3 other Atlantic provinces as well as Manitoba impose quarantine requirements on out-of-province visitors including Canadians. See Province of NL website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326140834/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/individuals-and-households/travel-advice-2/

On 26 march 2021, “border between the US and Canada has been closed for non-essential travel since March 21, 2020... the closure has now been extended through April 21, 2021...Americans are allowed to transit Canada enroute to a third country, but only if remaining in sterile transit...Canadians are allowed to travel to the US if arriving by air, though Americans aren’t allowed to travel to Canada...The US requires a negative coronavirus test no more than three days prior to traveling to the US, while Canada has even more stringent entry restrictions, and now even requires a hotel quarantine.” The rules for travel between Canada and non-US countries are similar. Flights to and from some destinations have been suspended.    See travel advice website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326142238/https://onemileatatime.com/us-canada-border-closure-extended/

As of 26 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In addition, Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians have been enhanced in many circumstances. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326142434/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html

As of 26 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In addition, Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians have been enhanced in many circumstances. As of 26 march 2021, the government of Canada continues with a “national public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.” See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326142749/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

As of 26 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are broadly similar. There is testing of asymptomatic individuals in some regions, but that practice remains the exception, not the rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326143021/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html
See note 23 March 2021

As of 26 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., in the province of British Columbia (BC): “Elementary school students are not required to wear masks and it remains a family decision.” See Governments of Canada and BC websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326144520/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326144301/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/education-training/k-12/covid-19-safe-schools

On 29 March 2021, Canada’s “National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) is recommending an immediate pause in the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine in all individuals less than 55 years of age in Canada. This is based on evidence of rare instances of vaccine-induced pro-thrombotic immune thrombocytopenia (VIPIT) following AstraZeneca vaccination reported in Europe”. All provinces and territories accepted this advice. On 5 april 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, schools are closed to in-person learning in the the Gatineau and Quebec City regions in the province of Quebec; Thunder Bay, Sudbury, Espanola and Manitoulin areas in the province of Ontario and in Regina, capital of the province of Saskatchewan. Most post-secondary institutions have been offering online classes during this academic year. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405110953/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-a-tale-of-two-covid-19-hot-spots-ontario-and-quebec-take-different/

On 5 april 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. In the province of Quebec, the government ordered “non-essential” businesses to close on 1 April for at least 10 days in the Gatineau and Quebec City regions. In two Maritime provinces (NS, PEI), businesses are open with relatively light restrictions. Rules elsewhere are somewhere in between with most businesses open with restrictions varying by jurisdiction. See GLobe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405110953/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-a-tale-of-two-covid-19-hot-spots-ontario-and-quebec-take-different/

See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405111740/https://www.toronto.ca/news/city-of-toronto-extends-cancellation-of-in-person-major-events-to-july-1/

On 5 april 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Exceptions are also made for an informal caregiver, or someone offering a service or support.” In the province of New Brunswick (NB), Edmundston area: “Social gatherings: Indoor – Your household bubble; Outdoor – 5 people or less with masks and physical distancing.” Limits elsewhere are higher varying by jurisdiction. As of 5 april 2021, evidence has not yet emerged that previous contact tracing problems have been fully resolved. For example, Canada’s Chief Public Health Officer recently repeated that “there must be sufficient contact tracing capacity and supports for effective isolation”. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405121729/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/04/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-april-1-2021.html

As of 5 april 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., in the province of British Columbia (BC): “Students in Kindergarten to grade 3 are encouraged to wear a mask indoors in schools and on school buses. Mask wearing remains a personal or family/caregiver choice for these students, and their choices must be respected.” See Governments of Canada and BC websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405122717/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405122906/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/education-training/k-12/covid-19-safe-schools

As of 5 april 2021 12:09PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 5,790,687 Canadians [15% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 706,144 Canadians [2%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved recently, but shipments will not arrive until later this month. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405194500/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405133338/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities3.html

On 6 april 2021, a newspaper reported that some provinces have considered “vaccine passports” to allow greater freedom of movement. Pfizer, Moderna, and AstraZeneca continue to be vaccines in use. Janssen approved, but not yet delivered. On 9 april 2021, schools are open in most of Canada. However, this week schools moved from in-person to online learning in the City of Toronto and two nearby suburban regions. Schools had already moved online in the Gatineau and Quebec City regions of the province of Quebec; Thunder Bay, Sudbury, Espanola and Manitoulin areas in the province of Ontario; and Regina, capital of the province of Saskatchewan. Most post-secondary institutions in Canada have been offering online classes during this academic year. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407223645/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-toronto-schools-to-close-in-person-classrooms-on-wednesday-shift-to/

On 9 april 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Effective 8 April, the province of ONtario decreed that “non-essential stores (including malls) will only be open for curbside pick-up and delivery, by appointment”. The province of Quebec ordered non-essential businesses to close on 1 April for at least 10 days in the Gatineau and Quebec City regions. In two Maritime provinces (NS, PEI), businesses are open with relatively light restrictions. Rules elsewhere are somewhere in between with most businesses open with restrictions varying by jurisdiction.   See government of Ontario and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210408141447/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/zones-and-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405110953/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-a-tale-of-two-covid-19-hot-spots-ontario-and-quebec-take-different/
